thread.title: New Ikea in Exeter offering jobs with £33,000 salaries | Devon Live

author: Devon Live
title: New Ikea in Exeter offering jobs with £33,000 salaries | Devon Live
text:
New Ikea in Exeter offering jobs with £33,000 salaries By Devon Live | Posted: June 04, 2017 By Jon Bayley Comments (0) 
Ikea will created 350 jobs with some paying up to £33,000 a year when it opens in Exeter next year. 
The Swedish flat pack furniture giant said the retail roles will see the total number of staff employed in the UK rise to 11,700. 
Last month an IKEA spokesperson said the store , off Newcourt Way and A379, will open in early summer 2018. 
The date is later than one suggested by Exeter City Council, who hoped it would be completed at Christmas this year. 
The Swedish home-ware giant is already looking to fill various posts based in Exeter - offering up to £33,000 a year for some roles. 
Jobs include HR administrator, sales department managers, HR business partner, kitchen production manager, customer restaurant manager and Swedish food market and bistro manager. 
Another 480 roles will be created in Sheffield, where Ikea will set up shop this summer. 
Speaking at a “groundbreaking" ceremony in Exeter last month , Ikea's UK boss Gillian Drakeford said: “As we continue to expand, we're delighted to bring investment to new areas across the country and create new opportunities for local communities. 
“This year we are celebrating Ikea's 30th anniversary in the UK, and we are seeing more demand from customers for more stores in areas closer to where they live." 
In November, Ikea said that UK revenues rose 8.9% to £1.72 billion in the year ending August 31, its fifth consecutive year of sales growth. 
Once opened, the new stores will leave Ikea with 22 outlets in the UK. The retailer also has four smaller format stores. 
Last year Ikea reiterated its commitment to investing in Britain following the Brexit vote, with Ms Drakeford saying at the time: “We believe there is a lot of opportunity in the UK. 
“We've been evaluating our newest stores and formats and yes, absolutely, there will be more stores. We will continue to invest in the UK."
